fields.value: House Unpassed Legislation 1832, Docket 11833, SC1/series 230, Petition of William Hall

authorName.value: Digital Archive of Massachusetts Anti-Slavery and Anti-Segregation Petitions, Massachusetts Archives, Boston MA

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Petition subject: Arrest

Original: http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:FHCL:10935281

Date of creation: (unknown)

Petition location: Boston

Legislator, committee, or address that the petition was sent to: Committee on the judiciary

Selected signatures:

  1. William Hall

Actions taken on dates: 1832-01-31,1832-02-20

Legislative action: Received in the House on January 31, 1832 and referred to a committee on the judiciary and leave to withdraw on February 20, 1832

Total signatures: 1

Legislative action summary: Received, referred, leave to withdraw

Legal voter signatures (males not identified as non-legal): 1

Female only signatures: No

Prayer format was printed vs. manuscript: Manuscript

Additional non-petition or unrelated documents available at archive: additional documents available

Additional archivist notes: Masons, arrested, constable, warrant, Benjamin Whitman, one of the police justices of the city of Boston, vagabond, negro, black and yallow fellow, negro and the molatto, both of the negro lodge of masons, evidence, house of correction, defrauded of his constitutional right, right to trial by jury, redress, investigation, power and authority of the police court, fraternity, Francis Oliver of Boston, freemason, settlement, statement, Thomas Powers, Knight Temple, printed, act of laying before the public, right to appeal, poor, New York, bail, imprisonment, witnesses, military service, veteran, Revolutionary War, publishing a statement of facts, John Thatcher, James Allyne, [James Allen?], clerk of the district court, Daniel Webster, haughty and self sufficient judge, Judge Roggers, Judge Rogers, George Reed, prison, lose his confidence in the government

Location of the petition at the Massachusetts Archives of the Commonwealth: House Unpassed 1832, Docket 11833

Acknowledgements: Supported by the National Endowment for the Humanities (PW-5105612), Massachusetts Archives of the Commonwealth, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University, Center for American Political Studies at Harvard University, Institutional Development Initiative at Harvard University, and Harvard University Library.

publicationCitation.value: D. Carpenter, N. Topich and G. Griffin. Digital Archive of Massachusetts Anti-Slavery and Anti-Segregation Petitions; House Unpassed Legislation 1832, Docket 11833, SC1/series 230. Massachusetts Archives. Boston, Mass.
